thread.title: Investors pick up Macquarie Green in North Ryde
thread.title_full: Investors pick up Macquarie Green in North Ryde | afr.com

author: Su-Lin Tan
title: Investors pick up Macquarie Green in North Ryde
text:
Toga Group's Macquarie Green sold 100 apartments on Saturday. Share on twitter Share on Google Plus by Su-Lin Tan Natasha Zohrabi says Australian Prudential Regulation Authority's clampdown on lending to property investors did not affect her.
The full-time investor bought three apartments at Toga Group's $140 million apartment project Macquarie Green, which launched Saturday in Sydney's north.
Ms Zohrabi said that while she was able to use two other existing properties as equity for her new investments, new investors might be caught.
"APRA hasn't affected me yet … New investors might have some risks," she said.
She sold an apartment in the same area – Macquarie Park in North Ryde – in 2011 for a 20 per cent capital gain.
While large capital gains are still attracting confident investors in the Sydney market, BIS Shrapnel warned last week that investors who buy new apartments "off-the-plan" could be at risk of settling the property down the track.
Domain group's senior economist Dr Andrew Wilson said the APRA rules also won't deter foreign investors.
"In fact I see increased levels in foreign interest in Australian property," he said. "If we are dissuading local investors, through lending conditions, it might make it easier for foreign investors.
 "The two-tier market – foreign versus local market – will continue. It's the old old story of the "law of unintended consequences".
Ms Zohrabi said: "For me, there is a big chance I will come out on top, for a property which is 20 minutes to the CBD, you can't go wrong," she said.
"Worse come to worse, I will sell two of of them if I don't make money and I'll come out even. I just don't think prices will drop, it might plateau if anything. So many people work in this area."
"These properties came to me as a blessing. It it works, great. If not, I never had the money to begin with."
Construction for Macquarie Green will begin in late 2015 and scheduled for completion in mid-2017. Toga also as another near-completion apartment project, Macquarie Central close by.
Toga's hotel division is backed by Singapore-listed Far East Orchard Limited, an offshoot of Singapore's largest private property developer, the Far East Organisation.
Toga, founded by the Sydney-based Vidor family, sold more than 100 Macquarie Green units from the 164 in stock.
The Marchese Partners-designed units are set in a gated community across four low-rise buildings.
